title: Resources
text:
Academic Job Market
On the job market?
Read the September newsletter from the American Statistical Association’s Section on Statistics in Genomics and Genetics (SSGG). I contributed some reflections and tips on applying for jobs at liberal arts colleges, and there is also great advice from others on applying for other types of jobs.
Check out this dataset containing salary ranges for statistics faculty positions. I created, and regularly update, this dataset by pulling salary ranges listed on official job postings shared via the ASA Community Job Postings Site, IsoStat mailing list, etc. As it becomes more common (or even required) for institutions to list salary ranges on job postings, I hope to be able to expand this resource even further!

title: About Me
text:
Hello! Welcome to my website.
My name is Md Mutasim Billah (EM-DEE MUTAA-seem bi-LAH) and I use the pronouns she/her/hers. I am a statistician and Visiting Assistant Professor of Statistics at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minnesota. I completed my PhD in Statistics at Michigan Technological University in Summer 2025. Before that, I earned both a B.Sc. and M.Sc. in Statistics, Biostatistics, & Informatics from the University of Dhaka, the top public university in Bangladesh. I also obtained a second M.Sc. in Statistics from Michigan Technological University.
In my personal life, I am a proud father of three wonderful children – as of 2025, my daughter is 7 years old, and my two sons are 3 years old and 18 months old. Outside of my academic work, I enjoy spending time outdoors with my family and friends or cooking a variety of foods. If you can’t find me anywhere, I might be busy playing soccer or exploring new worlds on PS5!.
The picture on this page is from a Juky 2024 trip to Pictured Rocks at Munising, Michigan.

title: Scholarship
text:
I am a biostatistician and statistical geneticist with scholarly interests in both statistical methods development and collaborative applications. My work focuses on developing and applying statistical methods to better understand human health and genetics, with a recent emphasis on genetic studies in populations with mixed ancestry (also known as “admixed populations”). Methodologically, I am particularly interested in addressing the statistical challenges posed by genetic data, such as their high dimensional nature, complicated correlation structure, and concerns about confounding and collider bias that can arise in these studies.
As a teacher-scholar at a small liberal arts institution, I engage undergraduates in this work through summer research projects, honors theses, and a newly designed course in statistical genetics. My close collaboration with students within and beyond the classroom has also inspired an increasing engagement in the scholarship of teaching and learning, with a focus thus far on alternative grading.

title: Scholarship
text:
Recent Projects


Statistical Genetics Methods

Understanding the power—and limitations—of admixture mapping studies, in collaboration with Macalester student Tina Chen (’25)
Illustrating potential pitfalls of using principal component analysis to infer and control for population structure in genome-wide association studies

Published in PLOS Genetics [link]

Updating STEAM—an R package that implements methods to adjust for multiple testing concerns that arise in genome-wide admixture mapping studies—in collaboration with Macalester students Zuofu Huang (’21), Tina Chen (’25), Sydney Ohr (’26), and Katelyn McClure (’26)

Available on GitHub




Collaborative Applications

Exploring disparities in B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) survival, in collaboration with Macalester student Sofia Barragan (’22) and investigators at the University of Minnesota

Published in Cancer Medicine [link]





Scholarship of Teaching and Learning


Exploring the four dimensions of equity (access, achievement, identity, power) posed by Gutiérrez (2009) as relates to the topic of grading

Published as a guest post on Grading for Growth [link] (and since recognized as one of the most popular posts of the year [link] and all time [link])

title: Md Mutasim Billah
text:
I am a Visiting Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minnesota.
At Macalester, I teach courses across our undergraduate statistics and data science curriculum. You can find a complete list of the courses I have taught, and their corresponding course materials, on my Teaching page.
My methodological research lies at the intersection of statistical genetics, biostatistics, and genomics. I develop novel statistical methods and computationally efficient bioinformatics tools—and leverage modern machine- and deep-learning approaches—to analyze high-dimensional next-generation sequencing and multi-omics data to identify genes and regulatory mechanisms underlying complex disease. In collaborative settings, I translate these approaches to address genetic and public-health questions across the biomedical sciences.
I am also developing a strong interest in SoTL (the scholarship of teaching and learning).
Read more about current and past projects on my Scholarship page.
I enjoy talking with students about research, graduate programs, and career opportunities in statistics. If you are a looking to learn more about opportunities in this field, please get in touch and/or check out the Resources page.
If you’re looking to learn more about me, otherwise, take a look at my CV or About Me page.
